items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Education Code Section 72122 provides that student disciplinary matters be considered by the Board of Trustees in closed session unless the student submits a written request to the Board Secretary that the hearing of the governing board be held as a public meeting.  As of the time of posting the agenda, no such request had been received, however the deadline for submission of the request had not yet passed.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Pursuant to Article XIII-B of the State Constitution and Government Code Section 7900 et seq., all community college districts are required to compute an annual appropriation limit.  The appropriation regulation limits the growth in community college district spending to be no faster than the growth in population and inflation.  The appropriation limit is adjusted annually for changes in the price index, population, and other applicable factors.
	 
The District's 2012-13 appropriation limit was $224,533,815.  The District's 2013-14 appropriation limit has been determined to be $228,311,767. 
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy
Additional contact names:
Hector Quinonez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Staff recommend that the Board adopt the attached resolution establishing the 2013-14 appropriation limit at $228,311,767.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The international student enrollment growth over the past eight years is due primarily to our increased international student recruitment efforts and to the intensive development of formal relationships with private educational advising agencies around the world. These agents send students overseas to undertake their college and university study. Over the past five years, we employed the services of this contractor, Gregory Barattini, who helped us to significantly increase the number of relationships we maintain with agents all over China, Indonesia, the rest of Southeast Asia and Europe. This expansion was a strong factor in the past few years in the District being able to increase international student enrollment despite the very challenging economic environment. In addition, the contractor helped reduce the District’s travel expenses by representing us at many international study abroad fairs and exhibitions.
	 
This contract would extend the services of Gregory Barattini for a one-year period starting July 1st. Mr. Barattini is a recognized professional expert and is the only individual known to me who provides this kind of international student recruitment representation to colleges and universities. For years, he worked as the senior vice president for marketing at several large international language school chains, recently represented Santa Monica College in a similar capacity over a four-year period, and has done an excellent job for FHDA over the past five years. His clients also include Berkeley Colleges in New York City and UCLA Extension. He fully understands what the District has to offer and how to market us abroad, and is on a first-name basis with a very large number of advising agents around the world. In addition, he is physically located in Indonesia, which allows him to travel inexpensively throughout the region and saves us considerable expenses. 
	 
The contractor will provide year-round recruitment representation in Southeast and South Asia, in Turkey and in Scandinavia. Specifically, he will:
Develop relationships for FHDA with additional new educational advising agents;
Strengthen relationships with existing agents;
Provide representation at large study abroad fairs and agent seminars; and
Provide ongoing recruitment and international marketing advice.
The contractor will provide these services to FHDA and to one or two other institutions, which will equally share in travel and related expenses.  He will not represent any other community college.
	 
The contractor will be paid $3,500.00 per month and will invoice us for the District’s share of his travel expenses, which will not exceed $50,000.00 for the academic year.
	 
Submitted by:
George Beers, ext. 7077
Additional contact names:
Judy Miner, ext. 7200
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College President, Judy Miner, recommends approval of the Independent Contractor Agreement for Gregory Barattini.

items.item_text_raw: 8. Gregory Barattini ICA

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In conjunction with District Board Policy 3205, Foothill College allows community groups and organizations the use of the facilities when that use does not interfere with, infringe on or impede the educational process. The intent is for the college to collect more rental fees while providing our community and organizations appropriate access to campus facilities.
	 
Foothill Fine Arts facilities are managed by the Fine Arts Division, while the remainder of campus facilities rentals are managed on an interim basis by Furniture, Fixtures, and Equipment (FF&E) coordinator under the supervision of the Facilities Director.  Foothill is in the process of hiring a Facilities Rental Coordinator who will be in charge of all campus facilities rentals starting FY 2013/14.
	 
Periodically, Foothill College reviews and revises the Facility Use Policy, Fees, Process & Procedures that govern the rental of facilities.
	 
Attached is the revised policy and fee schedule for the campus, effective July 2013, for the Board of Trustees’ review and approval. 
	 
Attachments included:
	 
1.   Foothill College Campus Facility Use Policies, Fees, Process and Procedures & Rental Rates effective July 1, 2013
2.   Fine Arts Facilities Rental Procedures, Rates and Fees effective July 1, 2013
	 
Submitted by:
Bernata Slater, ext 7364
Additional contact names:
Judy Miner, ext 7200
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In conjunction with District Board Policy 3205, De Anza College allows community groups and organizations the use of the facilities when that use does not interfere with, infringe on or impede the educational process.
	 
De Anza College celebrates the diversity of its student body and the communities from which they are drawn. The college believes in a rich diversity of viewpoint, age, cultural background, race, purpose, and social interaction. As a consequence, the College strives to ensure diverse groups and organizations have access to the use of our facilities.
	 
Periodically, De Anza College reviews and revises the Facility Use Policy, Fees, Process & Procedures we charge for the rental of facilities.
	 
Attached is the revised policy and fee schedule for the campus, effective July 2013, for Board of Trustee review and approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In conjunction with District Board Policy 3205, De Anza College allows community groups and organizations the use of the facilities when that use does not interfere with, infringe on or impede the educational process. 
	 
The College strives to ensure diverse groups and organizations have access to the use of its facilities and believe in supporting a rich diversity of viewpoint, age, cultural background, race, purpose, and social interaction.
	 
De Anza College is recommending supporting the following four major community events by donating facilities use. The rental groups will pay all direct costs.
	 
Fremont Union High Schools Foundation Crab Feed - April
Founded in 1983, the foundation is a non-profit, public-benefit corporation serving Cupertino, Lynbrook, Fremont, Homestead and Monta Vista high schools, acting as the primary fundraising organization for the school district. Much of the foundation's work relies heavily on parent and community contributions to fund district-wide programs. De Anza College normally charges for use of the main gym at a rate of $110 per hour for non-profit organizations. Parking is normally charged at $3 per space. We request these two fees be waived. The rental group will pay all direct costs.
	 
The Cherry Blossom Festival - April
The Cherry Blossom Festival honoring Cupertino's sister city of Toyokawa, Japan, is an annual event held at Memorial Park each April. This event offers a wide selection of Japanese food and beverages, entertainment, demonstrations, cultural exhibits, art, crafts and clothing for sale. The festival benefits the non-profit Cupertino Sister City Committee, which promotes friendship and student exchange programs between the two cities. Local non-profit organizations that support services for disadvantaged youth, sports, music and language programs have booths to raise funds for their groups. Parking is normally charged at $3 per space. We request this fee be waived. The rental group will pay any direct costs.
	 
The Kiwanis Special Games – May
The Kiwanis Special Games were created to address the physical and emotional needs of the substantial number of extremely challenged children in the schools of our region. Two Adaptive PE teachers and Los Altos Kiwanian, Walter Chronert, first organized the Games in 1979. Under Walt’s leadership, spanning more then 25 years, the Games flourished from modest beginnings involving just the Los Altos Kiwanis Club to the regional event they are today.  The Games are be run by about 250 Kiwanians, 300 Kiwanis student volunteers and over 1,000 school and community volunteers. The Los Altos Kiwanis Club and The De Anza Kiwanis Club of Cupertino manage the event. The athletic fields are normally charged at a rate of $90 per hour; the stadium at a rate of $131 per hour; and the track at a rate of $66 per hour for non-profit organizations. Parking is normally charged at $3 per space. We request these fees be waived. The rental group will pay all direct costs.
	 
Silicon Valley Fall Festival - September
The Silicon Valley Fall Festival is held annually and sponsored by the Cupertino Rotary Club and The World Journal. The event is held at Memorial Park and Quinlan Community Center. Parking is normally charged at $3 per space. We request this fee be waived. The rental group will pay any direct costs.
	 
The President is seeking approval of a facilities rental arrangement with these groups that is outside of the standard Board approved facilities rental schedule.
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy, President, ext 8705
Additional contact names:
Letha Jeanpierre, VP Finance, ext 8976
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President, Brian Murphy, recommends approval of a facilities rental arrangement with these groups that is outside of the standard Board approved Facilities rental schedule.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis. In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District’s
	investments as of March 31, 2013.
The District’s cash of $244,803,977.71 is invested in the County’s Commingled Investments Pool. As of on March 31, 2013, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was
	0.49%. As a comparison to prior year for the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.24%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.10%; and the State of California
	Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) yield was 0.27%.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Currently the District holds a contract with ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corporation for routine and regular monthly service on elevators and accessibility lifts at both Foothill and De Anza colleges.  Furthermore, not all equipment is covered by this contract; some elevators and accessibility lifts are currently covered by manufacturer’s warranty that are due to expire about December 30, 2013. For economy of scale and consistency, the facilities and operations department desires one contractor to be responsible for routine monthly maintenance of all district owned vertical transportation equipment not covered under manufacturer’s warranty.
	 
The bid specifications require elevator contractors to provide service on 29 passenger elevators, 1 passenger service elevator, 1 dumbwaiter, 1 stage lift at Flint Center for the Performing Arts, 1 sidewalk elevator, 1 freight elevator, 1 platform elevator, and 12 accessibility lifts at Foothill and De Anza colleges. The scope of services provides detailed information regarding the expectations of the contractor.
	 
It is the Districts’ intent to enter into a one-year agreement, renewable for up to four additional one-year terms upon mutual agreement between both parties for this service.  At the beginning of each additional term, the District reserves the right to include additional elevators in the monthly service contract.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on May 3 and May 10, 2013. The “Invitation to Bid” was also posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 30, 2013 in the Purchasing Services office. Two (2) contractors attended the mandatory job walk in which all sites at both campuses were visited and both contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount – 
Initial 12 months service
Elevator Services Company of Central California Inc.
$ 76,860
ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corporation
$ 81,018
	 
	 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Elevator Services Company of Central California Inc. (Elevator Services).  Historically, Elevator Services has performed maintenance and repair services for the District.  They have also recently completed a project that included the design, acquisition and installment of a platform lift in Building A8 at De Anza College.  The cost of the regular and routine monthly services will be paid for from Plant Services General Funds (B Budget).
	 
Submitted by:
 Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
 Charles, Allen, Lester Lyons
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Executive Director of Facilities and Operations Charles Allen to enter into a one-year contract with Elevator Service Company of Central California Inc. in the amount of $76,860 for vertical transportation maintenance services, renewable for up to four (4) one-year terms, all in accordance with Bid Document 1642.

Amount:  $30,055
For:
	 
At Building 5100 demolition for door frame openings, furnish & install nailers for casework not shown on drawings, and replace existing leaking fire sprinkler valve.  At Building 5600 demolition for door & window frame openings not shown on drawings, and provide additional framing at sagging ceiling, At Building 5700 remove additional hazardous sub-flooring, furnish and install nailers for casework, furnish & install seismic overhead projector bracing not shown on drawings, modify floor finishes as requested by District, and provide power to (E) fan coil unit not shown in drawings. At Building 5800 demolition for door & window frame openings not shown on drawings. 
General change to replace Carpet C2 in with Carpet C1.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal to 0.5% of the base contract value. 
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Ratification

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project consists of renovating seven (7) existing showers at the PE-6 Building at De Anza College to meet current California Building Code Standards.  Interior demolition includes: removal and salvaging of colored ceramic tile, demolition of ceramic floor & wall tiles, removal of shower heads & shower faucet panels, removal of existing grab bars, and miscellaneous wall and ceiling demolition. Installation includes: new shower partitions, new ADA-approved shower seats, new ADA-approved grab bars, replacing or re-installing ceramic floor & wall tile, re-installation of shower heads & shower faucet panels, and the patch and paint of gypsum wallboard.
					 
Arch-Pac, Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
					 
Bid Document #1644-200F was legally advertised on April 5, 2013 and April 12, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Eight (8) contractors attended the Mandatory Bid Walk that was held on April 18, 2013.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 14, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  Only one bidder submitted a bid, R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors (R.C. Benson) for the base bid proposal amount of $100,000. 
Since only one bid was received, Gilbane staff contacted several contractors that attended the mandatory job walk and asked why they did not submit bids.  The common answers were: 1) the project’s scope was smaller than what they want to dedicate resources to in this economy, and 2) the project’s tight summer schedule did not fit into their overall staffing schedule, which is typically very busy during the summer.
					 
Furthermore, Alejandro Pinnick of Arch Pac, Inc. and Gilbane staff also conclude that the reason only one bid was submitted and it was at a higher cost than the architectural estimate was due to 1) multiple trades constructing small components of work in various rooms and 2) the overlapping integration of physically getting work purchased, prepared, and executed in the time frame the District required. 
					 
The bid price of $100,000 for the Base Bid Proposal Amount submitted by R.C. Benson exceeds the architect’s estimate of $80,000, however, it is within the overall Project #200F budget of $162,000.  Therefore, the Measure C bond team recommends award a contract for the base bid proposal amount to R.C. Benson.  This project is funded by Measure C.
					 
R.C. Benson and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  Purchasing Services staff has confirmed that R.C. Benson successfully completed Project 153C, Psychology Offices Acoustical Improvement at Foothill College in 2011 and Project 116, Deck Repair and Window Replacement for the Japanese Cultural Center at Foothill College in 2013.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Donna Jones Dulin, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1644-200F, Pool Tile & Plaster Replacement added work PE-6 ADA Shower Upgrades at De Anza College in the aggregate amount of $100,000 to R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors.
